body:
Hello @ForFyy, thank you for your interest in our work! Please visit our [Custom Training Tutorial](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/Train-Custom-Data) to get started, and see our [Google Colab Notebook](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/master/tutorial.ipynb), [Docker Image](https://hub.docker.com/r/ultralytics/yolov3), and [GCP Quickstart Guide](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/wiki/GCP-Quickstart) for example environments. 
  
If this is a bug report, please provide screenshots and **minimum viable code to reproduce your issue**, otherwise we can not help you.
Pretrained weights are trained on COCO 2014, so if you use COCO 2017 you will get false results.

> Pretrained weights are trained on COCO 2014, so if you use COCO 2017 you will get false results.

thanks a lot for answering!

@ForFyy to test with coco2014:
`python3 test.py --data coco2014.data`
...Can I  send you the last.pt ， model.py and .cfg file by email, if possible, can you just run it for one times to see the testing result?
No, we don’t have time to view your custom model. mAP reproducible code is in the readme mAP section, suggest you start there.

> No, we don’t have time to view your custom model. mAP reproducible code is in the readme mAP section, suggest you start there.

I understand,thanks a lot for answering anyway!
This issue is stale because it has been open 30 days with no activity. Remove Stale label or comment or this will be closed in 5 days.

@glenn-jocher 
Could you please clarify why the `trainvalno5k.txt` and `5k.txt`(minival) used by YOLO are not the same as `train2017.txt` and `val2017.txt`?

According other object detection work such as [RetinaMask](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1901.03353.pdf) which follows [ION](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1512.04143.pdf), the 135K and 5K from COCO 2014 should be the same as COCO 2017.

> We follow common practice [3], using the COCO trainval135k split (union of 2014train 80k and a subset of 35k images from 2014val 40k) for training and the minival (remaining 5k images from 2014val 40k) for evaluation.

> COCO trainval135k is also called COCO 2017 train and the minival is COCO 2017 val.
@farleylai coco 2014 and 2017 are obviously different datasets, otherwise they would share the same name. See http://cocodataset.org/#download
@farleylai the 14 split we inherited from the darknet repos, so you may want to inquire about split specific questions there.

@glenn-jocher

According the COCO website:

> the split is now 118K/5K for train/val. The same exact images are used, and no new annotations for detection/keypoints are provided.

Therefore, the changes are expectable because most research works use the same custom splits for COCO 2014 which should become the default in COCO 2017 with 5K in val.  Otherwise, the 5K `minival` results cannot be comparable with recent detection model zoo such as `detectron2` and `mmdetection` which standardize the results based on `val2017` already.

Actually, [detectron repo](https://github.com/facebookresearch/Detectron/blob/master/detectron/datasets/data/README.md#coco-minival-annotations) explicitly describes the COCO Minival Annotations as follows:

> Our custom minival and valminusminival annotations are available for download here. Please note that minival is exactly equivalent to the recently defined 2017 val set. Similarly, the union of valminusminival and the 2014 train is exactly equivalent to the 2017 train set.

In short, COCO_2017_train = COCO_2014_train + `valminusminival` , COCO_2017_val = `minival`, where `valminusminival` and `minival` are from COCO 2014 val as the custom splits used in early object detection work.

Now, looking into `instances_minival2014.json`, the last 5 files are listed as follows:
```
COCO_val2014_000000581317.jpg
COCO_val2014_000000581357.jpg
COCO_val2014_000000581482.jpg
COCO_val2014_000000581615.jpg
COCO_val2014_000000581781.jpg
```

The above is the same as the last 5 files in `val2017`:
```
$> ls images/val2017 | sort | tail
000000581317.jpg
000000581357.jpg
000000581482.jpg
000000581615.jpg
000000581781.jpg
```

However, the `5K.txt` used by YOLO for COCO 2014 lists the following:
```
$> sort 5k.txt | tail
./coco/images/val2014/COCO_val2014_000000581655.jpg
../coco/images/val2014/COCO_val2014_000000581731.jpg
../coco/images/val2014/COCO_val2014_000000581781.jpg
../coco/images/val2014/COCO_val2014_000000581887.jpg
../coco/images/val2014/COCO_val2014_000000581899.jpg
```

It would be surprising if YOLO does not follow the same convention. An inquiry about the splits on the darknet repo would be necessary soon. As for now, the pretrained YOLOv4 weights produces different results on the 5K from COCO 2014 and the val2017 using the `test.py` script which may cause quite a bit confusion.

@farleylai all pretrained models trained with this repo are trained on coco2014. I can't speak for darknet trained models.

In any case, any model is trainable on any dataset, the only condition is that 2014-trained models may not be tested on val2017 and vice versa.

We are launching a new repo in the next few days at https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5 which features pretrained model from 2017 only. 

So the easy easy way to remember this is that this repo only offers pretrained 2014 models, and yolov5 repo will only offer pretrained 2017 models.
